LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of the Philippines 
   
The Proposal  A  loan  of  $500,000,000  is  proposed  to  support  the  Government’s 
countercyclical expenditure program. The loan is to be provided under 
the Countercyclical Support Facility of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) as a single tranche. 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsector): Public sector management (economic and public 
affairs management) 
Theme (subtheme): Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic 
stability) 
Location impact: National (high impact) 
   
Environment  Category C 
Assessment 
   
Rationale  The global crisis, which intensified after September 2008, has affected 
the  Philippine  economy  and  social  sectors  in  four  related  respects: 
(i) the first-round effects of the global financial crisis had repercussions 
for the domestic financial sector in the second half of 2008; (ii) the 
second-round effects of devastated global demand has hurt the real 
economy, sharply lowering its growth prospects for 2009; (iii) the impact 
on fiscal policy has resulted in declining tax revenue collection and a 
larger government budget deficit than initially projected, at a time of 
limited access to global credit markets; and (iv) the economic and fiscal 
policy impacts threaten to undo recent gains in social policy spending, 
unemployment reduction, and poverty reduction programs.  
Given the second-round effects on the real economy and emerging 
fiscal  constraint,  the  Government  of  the  Philippines  asked  ADB  to 
provide a countercyclical support loan of $500 million to support its 
public expenditure program for 2009. The Government is concerned 
about its ability to ensure predictability in budget financing as it has 
already provided a temporary fiscal stimulus within its medium-term 
fiscal program. The Government projects gross financing requirements 
for 2009 at P451 billion in domestic financing and $4.3 billion in external 
financing, including domestic and external debt that matures in 2009. 
The  Government's  external  debt  amortization  profile  is  projected  to 
remain relatively high in 2010 with as much as $6.0 billion maturing in 
2010. Therefore, the countercyclical support loan will provide additional 
financing to the Government for its needed larger fiscal stimulus. This 
will allow the Government to stimulate an economic recovery, protect its 
social spending and poverty reduction programs, and continue with its 
longer-term development objectives in 2009.   
The Government announced its countercyclical expenditure program in 
2009  and  integrated  it  into  the  2009  budget.  Since  the  national 
government budget does not have automatic stabilizers embedded on

ii 
 
the expenditure side, the countercyclical program was needed to focus 
on advancing infrastructure projects already in the investment pipeline, 
scale  up  social  assistance  and  public  employment  programs,  and 
implement policy measures to expedite budget disbursements. Overall, 
noninterest expenditure is programmed to rise by 20% in 2009 over 
2008,  providing  a  much-needed  boost  to  the  economy.  The  2009 
national budget substantially increases spending on the social sectors; 
this will help mitigate adverse impacts of the economic contraction on 
the poor. The proposed loan will support the Government's ongoing and 
scaled up social assistance programs and infrastructure programs in 
the social sector and agriculture. 
 
The  Government  has  scaled  up  its  social  assistance  and  poverty 
reduction programs to protect the most vulnerable from the effects of 
the  economic  contraction.  These  programs  include  the  hunger 
mitigation  program,  self-employment  assistance  kaunlaran  (SEA-K) 
program,  food  for  school  program,  family-based  conditional  cash 
transfer  program  (CCT),  community-based  development  program 
(KALAHI), and comprehensive livelihood and emergency employment 
program (CLEEP). These social assistance programs are implemented 
within the framework of the Government's 2007 national social welfare 
program.  Under  this  framework,  the  National  Economic  and 
Development  Authority  introduced  a  national  definition  of  social 
protection  and  identified  types  of  programs  covered.  In  2008  the 
Government  established  an  institutional  framework  for  enhanced 
delivery of social protection programs that specifically assigns operating 
responsibilities  of  the  National  Social  Welfare  Program  to  the 
Department of Social Welfare and Development. 
 
Spending on infrastructure also increased and procurement advanced. 
The  2009  budgets  for  key  infrastructure  agencies  were  significantly 
increased. In real terms, the Department of Public Works and Highways 
budget  increased  by  13%  over  2008  and  the  Department  of 
Agriculture's  budget  rose  by  52%.  To  ensure  the  Government's 
countercyclical program would be timely and effective by the second 
semester of 2009, these agencies agreed to obligate at least 60% of 
their total 2009 spending program during the first semester of 2009.  
 
Support for the countercyclical expenditure program is anchored by 
ADB’s  existing  loan  programs  to  the  Philippines,  especially  policy 
dialogue with the Government under the Development Policy Support 
Program (DPSP) approved in February 2007. The DPSP, structured as 
a  program  cluster  comprising  three  single  tranche  operations  (or 
subprograms) over 2006–2009, focuses on a broad policy agenda that 
addresses thematic and cross-cutting issues in four core areas: (i) fiscal 
sustainability  and  macroeconomic  stability,  (ii) governance  in  public 
financial management (PFM) and anticorruption in key revenue-raising 
agencies, (iii) the investment climate, and (iv) enhancement of human 
capital and social inclusion. The third subprogram (scheduled to be 
submitted to the ADB Board of Directors for consideration in September 
2009) includes a postprogram monitoring framework for 12 months to

iii 
create the basis for continuous policy dialogue and engagement during 
the  critical  period  of  2009/10  prior  to  the  formulation  of  a  new 
government after the Philippine presidential elections in May 2010. 
 
Objective, Scope  The loan is to provide support for the Government's countercyclical 
and Coverage of  expenditure program for 2009 and therefore ensure predictability in its 
Loan  budget financing given the necessity for temporary fiscal expansion. 
This will allow the Government to stimulate the economic recovery, 
protect  its  social  spending  and  poverty  reduction  programs  and 
objectives, and continue with its longer-term development objectives in 
2009.   
Financing Plan  A loan of $500,000,000 under the Countercyclical Support Facility from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources will be provided under ADB's London 
interbank-offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan will have 
a 5-year term including a grace period of 3 years, an interest rate 
determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility plus 
200  basis  points  (bps),  a  commitment  charge  of  75  bps  on  the 
undisbursed loan balance, and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan 
agreement.  
 
Period and  The  loan  will  be  used  to  support  the  Government's  countercyclical 
Tranching  expenditure program implemented from February 2009 to December 
2010, the end period specified for the countercyclical support facility; 
the single tranche loan of $500 million is to be disbursed upon loan 
effectiveness.  
   
Counterpart Funds  The  Government  will  use  the  local  currency  counterpart  funds 
generated  by  the  loan  proceeds  to  help  maintain  current  social 
expenditure and infrastructure spending. 
   
Executing Agency   Department of Finance 
   
Implementation  The coordinating committee, initiated under the Development Policy 
Arrangements  Support  Program  and  chaired  by  the  Department  of  Finance 
undersecretary, will be responsible for coordinating implementation of 
the  Government's  countercyclical expenditure  program  together  with 
the  Department  of  Budget  and  Management  (DBM)  and  National 
Economic and Development Authority. The committee will meet semi-
annually  to  monitor  progress  and  oversee  program  implementation. 
ADB may be invited to participate in the meetings as an observer. 
   
Procurement and  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
Disbursement  costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured 
in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. The loan proceeds 
will be disbursed to the Borrower in accordance with the provisions of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans (1998).

iv 
 
Benefits and  The economy and the poor are beneficiaries:  
Beneficiaries  (i)  Higher  infrastructure  spending  will  generate  long-term  growth, 
stimulate investment, create jobs, and raise incomes. 
(ii) Improved  social  sector  outcomes  will  result  from  increased 
spending;  better  targeted  social  assistance  programs;  and 
implementation of the CCT program linked to better outcomes for 
child  education  and  health,  and  the  comprehensive  livelihood 
employment  and  emergency  employment  program  (providing 
crisis-related relief to unemployed workers). 
(iii) The  reduction  of  the  budget  financing  gap  will  support 
macroeconomic stability within the medium-term fiscal program. 
 
Risks and  The loan supplements financing from other ADB programs such as the 
Assumptions  proposed third subprogram of the DPSP. The DPSP is firmly embedded 
in  the  Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan  2004–2010;  the 
Philippines Development Forum; and the Government’s ongoing sector 
strategies covering its fiscal program, tax administration reform, PFM, 
procurement  reform,  investment  competitiveness,  rural  development, 
and social protection. 
 
Risks include the following:  
(i)  The global financial crisis has hurt the Philippines. A prolonged 
global recession and dysfunctional credit markets will place further 
stress on the fiscal situation and the budget financing gap as 
about $8.4 billion of external public debt matures in 2009 and 
2010.  The  economic  slowdown,  coupled  with  a  decline  in 
remittances, will result in increased poverty incidence in 2009. 
However, this will be partially offset through the scaling up of the 
CCT, implementation of the CLEEP and other social assistance 
programs, and increase of infrastructure development in 2009 and 
2010. 
(ii) The  absorptive  capacity  of  key  spending  agencies  may  be 
stretched  impacting  the  timeliness  and  effectiveness  of  the 
countercyclical  expenditure  program.  The  Government  has 
introduced  several  policy  measures  to  expedite  disbursements 
and this will mitigate some of these constraints. 
(iii) Some  social  assistance  programs  and  infrastructure  are 
vulnerable  to  leakages,  poor  targeting,  and  corruption.  The 
Government is committed to addressing these problems through 
instruments  such  as  public  financial  reforms  and  procurement. 
The Government Procurement Policy Board continues to make 
substantial  progress  in  implementing  the  Procurement  Reform 
Law  of  2003  and  its  3-year  action  plan  to  strengthen  the 
institutional  framework;  capacity  development  of  procurement 
officers; and enforcement of the law, including the expansion of 
the  electronic  procurement  portal  (PhilGEPS),  which  aims  to 
increase transparency and enhance competition in procurement. 
The  Procurement  Transparency  Group,  which  includes 
government  agencies  and  major  civil  society  organizations  as 
members, was established to track and monitor the procurement 
of selected infrastructure projects.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of the Philippines for Countercyclical Support (PHI-CS). The Development 
Policy Letter confirming the Government's countercyclical expenditure program and its medium-
term development program is in Appendix 1. The status of the Government's compliance with 
the access criteria is in Appendix 2. 
 
II.   REQUEST FOR ASSISTANCE FROM THE COUNTERCYCLICAL SUPPORT 
FACILITY  
2.  The  proposed  loan  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  (CSF)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) comes at a critical time for the Philippines. It is designed to maintain 
momentum of the country’s key development efforts at a challenging time of global financial 
market  failure  and  the  first  global  recession  since  World  War II.  The  global  crisis,  which 
intensified after September 2008, has affected the Philippine economy and social sectors in four 
related respects: (i) the first-round effects of the global financial crisis impacted the domestic 
financial sector in the second half of 2008; (ii) the second-round effects of reduced global 
demand  have  hurt  the  real  economy  and  may  have  put  the  Philippines  in  an  economic 
recession in the first half of 2009; (iii) the impact on fiscal policy has resulted in declining tax 
revenue and a larger government budget deficit than initially projected, at a time of limited 
access to global credit markets; and (iv) the economic and fiscal policy impacts threaten to undo 
recent  gains  in  social  policy  spending,  unemployment  reduction,  and  poverty  reduction 
programs.  
3.  Given the second-round effects on the real economy and the emerging fiscal constraint, 
the Government of the Philippines asked ADB to provide a countercyclical support loan (PHI-
CS) of $500 million to support its 2009 public expenditure program, including its ongoing and 
scaled  up  social  assistance  and  emergency  employment  programs,  among  others.  The 
Government  is  concerned  about  ensuring  predictability  in  its  budget  financing,  given  the 
necessity for temporary fiscal stimulus within the medium-term fiscal program. The Government 
projects gross financing requirements for 2009 at P451.8 billion in domestic financing and $4.3 
billion in external financing, including domestic and external debt that matures in 2009. The 
Government's external debt amortization profile is projected to remain relatively high in 2010, 
with  as  much  as  $6.0  billion  maturing  in  2010  (Table 4).  Therefore,  the  loan  will  provide 
additional financing to the Government for the larger fiscal stimulus now needed. 
4.  The Government has met the access criteria under the CSF (Appendix 2).1 First, the 
economy has been adversely impacted by the global economic crisis. This impact is manifested 
in  several  ways.  Economic  growth  contracted  by  2.3%  in  the  first  quarter  of  2009  on  a 
seasonally adjusted quarter-on-quarter basis, and the index of leading economic indicators 
suggests the economy may have continued to contract in the second quarter. The collapse in 
exports and stagnant inflows of remittances were the key factors behind this sharper than 
expected economic contraction. The Philippines is also experiencing temporary fiscal constraint 
because of the economic slowdown. Tax revenue collection declined by 5.2% in the first 6 
months of 2009 compared with 10% growth in 2008. The 2009 national government budget 
deficit is now projected to widen from the original programmed deficit of 0.5% of GDP to 3.2%, 
still relatively low by international standards, reflecting the Government's cautious fiscal stance.

5.  Second, the Government continues to maintain sound macroeconomic management of 
the increased downside risks to the economy arising from the global financial crisis. This is 
reflected in a strong external balance with gross international reserves equivalent to 6.3 months 
of import cover, a low inflation environment, and a sound and liquid banking system. The 
Government  has  operated  primary  budget  surpluses  for  the  past  3  years,  and  reduced 
nonfinancial public sector debt from more than 101.0% of GDP in 2003 to 59.9% in 2008. While 
public debt is broadly sustainable, it is vulnerable to exchange rate risks as 40% of public debt 
is denominated in foreign currencies (Appendix 3).  
 
6.  Third,  the  Government  has  announced  a  countercyclical  expenditure  program  and 
incorporated  it  into  the  2009  budget  enacted  in  February  2009.  The  program  focuses  on 
advancing infrastructure projects already in the Government's investment pipeline, scaling up 
social assistance (such as the conditional cash transfer program CCT) and public employment 
programs, implementing the CLEEP program, and introducing policy measures to expedite 
budget disbursements. Overall, noninterest expenditure is programmed to rise by 20% in 2009 
over 2008, providing a much-needed boost to the economy in the second half of 2009.  
 
7.  The PHI-CS loan is anchored by ADB’s existing loan programs to the Philippines and 
especially through policy dialogue with the Government under the Development Policy Support 
Program (DPSP) approved by the ADB Board of Directors in February 2007 (Appendix 4). The 
DPSP is structured as a program cluster comprising three single-tranche operations (three 
subprograms over 2006–2009) with a well-defined, medium-term framework. Policy triggers (or 
expected prior actions) for subsequent subprograms ensures continuous dialogue between the 
Government, ADB, other development partners, and stakeholders. The DPSP aims to help the 
Government achieve its medium- to long-term goals of sustained high economic growth, lower 
unemployment, and poverty reduction. It focuses on a broad policy agenda that addresses 
thematic and crosscutting issues in four core areas: (i) fiscal sustainability and macroeconomic 
stability,  (ii)  governance  in  public  financial  management  (PFM)  and  anticorruption  in  key 
revenue-raising agencies, (iii) investment climate, and (iv) enhancement of human capital and 
social inclusion. These are all key outcomes and outputs of the ADB country strategy and 
program 2005–2007 for the Philippines.2 
 
8.  Under subprogram 1 of the DPSP, the Government implemented a series of measures 
to address the fiscal imbalance, resulting in a swift and impressive turnaround in the fiscal 
situation and improved macroeconomic stability in 2006 and 2007. Subprogram 2 for 2008 built 
on  reforms  initiated  under  subprogram  1  for  fiscal  consolidation  and  strengthening  of 
governance  in  PFM  and  procurement.  These  measures  resulted  in  successful  fiscal 
consolidation and provided much needed fiscal space for increasing spending on the social 
sectors and infrastructure in 2007 and 2008. The third subprogram, scheduled to be submitted 
to the ADB Board of Directors for consideration in September 2009, increases the focus on  
(i) institutionalizing governance programs such as the anticorruption revenue programs in the 
Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) and Bureau of Customs (BOC), (ii) the investment climate, 
and (iii) the social sectors. While the third subprogram is the final of the series, it includes a new 
postprogram monitoring framework for 12 months to create the basis for continuous policy 
dialogue and engagement during the critical 2009/10 period prior to the formulation of a new 
government after the Philippine presidential elections in May 2010. The monitoring framework 
focuses on the Government's short-term plan for advancing its reforms in fiscal policy, PFM, and 
selected areas in investment climate and poverty, supported by ADB, the Government of Japan, 
and other development partners' technical and program assistance (Appendix 5 provides the

III.  THE GLOBAL CRISIS AND COUNTRY CONTEXT 
A.  The Global Crisis and its Impact on the Philippine Economy, Employment, and 
Poverty 
9.  The global financial turmoil has impacted developed and most developing economies, 
including the Philippines. The impact on developing countries has varied, but generally the crisis 
adversely impacted access to global financial markets; and resulted in a sharp downturn in the 
real  economy  with  ensuing  fiscal  stress,  and  higher  unemployment  and  poverty.  The 
International  Monetary  Fund  projects  the  global  economy  will  contract  this  year  and  only 
moderately recover next year as financial market stabilization will take longer than previously 
envisaged.  Developing  country  access  to  international  credit  will  remain  curtailed  as  a 
consequence.3  
 
10.  Spillovers from the global financial crisis on the Philippine domestic financial sector—
especially banking—have been relatively muted because of limited exposure to troubled US 
assets, and low exposure to securitization and off-balance-sheet activities. The banking system 
remains sound with a capital adequacy ratio at 14% and gross nonperforming loans at 3.6% as 
of the end of May 2009. The equity market was impacted with equity prices falling by as much 
as 50% in 2008, in line with the experience of regional neighbors; it has since stabilized.  
 
11.  However,  the  global  credit  crunch  that  emerged  in  September  2008  did  hurt  the 
Philippines by making access to international debt markets more expensive, for both the public 
and private sectors. Yields on medium-term domestic bonds increased by nearly 350 basis 
points (bps) in October 2008 and the Philippines’ international bond spreads surged to 800 bps 
on 24 October 2008. The Philippines was among the first of the emerging markets to reenter 
global  capital  markets  with  a  dollar  bond  issue  in  January  2009.  It  successfully  raised 
$1.5 billion at an average yield of 8.5%, an increase in the bond spread by 300 bps over 
precrisis levels. At that time, the Philippines took advantage of a liquid dollar domestic market 
due to the steady inflow of remittances and a collapse in the demand for trade finance, with 
more than 40% of bond issuance taken up by domestic banks. In July 2009, the Government 
raised an additional $750.0 million at an average yield of 6.6%. While global credit markets have 
shown  signs  of  recovery  in  recent  months  and  spreads  have  started  to  decrease  toward 
precrisis levels, global markets remain fragile and at the end of June 2009 spreads on Philippine 
international bonds increased again from an average spread of 270 bps in early June 2009 to 
320  bps  (Figure  1).  Also  indicative  of  elevated  risk,  the  yield  curve  on  sovereign  dollar 
denominated bonds is much steeper in 2009 compared to its position in 2007 and early 2008.4

12.  The  Second  Round  Effects  of  Global  Demand  Destruction.  The  second-round

14.  The  global  financial  crisis  has  affected  fiscal  policy  in  three  ways.  First,  with  the 
contraction in the economy, it is necessary for the Government to provide a modest stimulus in 
2009 while maintaining medium-term fiscal discipline. Second, the contraction in the economy in 
the first quarter of 2009 resulted in a decline in tax collections of about 5.2% in the first 6 
months of 2009 over the same period in 2008, and about 20% below its original 2009 budget 
target (Figure 2).5 The decline in tax collection was broad-based across most types of taxes, 
although the drop in foreign trade tax collection was larger than others. Customs collection 
decreased by 8.3% (of which value-added tax on plummeting imported goods fell 12.9%) and 
BIR's collections fell by 5.1% on a year-on-year basis. ADB staff assessments indicate that tax 
revenues  have  historically  exhibited  a  systematic,  moderate  pro-cyclical  pattern  in  the 
Philippines, that is, during periods of fast economic growth, direct and indirect taxes grow faster 
than nominal GDP; and during sharp slowdowns, taxes fall faster than nominal GDP. ADB staff 
estimates based on a low-growth scenario for 2009 and 2010 indicate that the tax–GDP ratio 
will decline for FY2009; some of the decline will carry over into 2010 as corporate tax losses are 
carried forward. As a result of the increased spending and projected decline in revenues, the

B.  The Government's Macroeconomic Management 
15.  Appropriate and Responsive Policy. The Government's macroeconomic policy stance 
to the increased downside risks to the economy from the global crisis has been appropriate and 
responsive. Several key macroeconomic indicators showed improvement in 2009 over 2008.  
On the external side, the current account is in surplus of about 4.9% of GDP for the first quarter 
of 2009. Gross international reserves continue to accumulate and reached $39.5 billion at the 
end of May 2009, equivalent to 6.3 months of import cover and three times higher than external 
debt maturing this year. Conventionally, at least 3 months of import coverage is considered a 
sufficient buffer against modest shocks to the balance of payments. On the monetary side, the 
Central Bank of the Philippines (BSP) has operated an appropriate and timely monetary policy 
stance throughout the crisis. In early 2008 it raised interest rates to counter the threat of 
second-round inflationary pressures arising from the surge in global commodity prices. It then 
shifted to an expansionary monetary position at the end of 2008 to provide sufficient liquidity to 
the banking system against the backdrop of rapidly falling inflation. The BSP currently maintains 
a neutral monetary stance. Inflation fell to 0.2% (year-on-year) in July 2009, well below BSP's 
inflation target range of 2.5%–4.5% for 2009. Inflation is expected to remain benign for the rest 
of this year, indicative of the slump in domestic economic activity.  
 
16.  The Government's response to mitigating the risk of the global financial crisis on the 
Philippine financial sector involves a number of preemptive measures aimed at increasing 
liquidity in the domestic banking system, assuring confidence of depositors, and strengthening 
BSP's lender of last resort facility. These measures include (i) BSP strengthened its lender of 
last resort facility by increasing its budget for the peso rediscounting facility from P20 billion to 
P40 billion on 14 November 2008, and opened a dollar repo facility on 20 October 2008 to 
ensure  dollar  liquidity  with  the  banks’  dollar-denominated  Philippine  sovereign  bonds  as 
underlying collateral; (ii) BSP increased liquidity in the banking system by easing monetary 
policy including reducing the reserve requirement by 2 percentage points, (iii) BSP allowed 
financial institutions to temporarily reclassify their investments in debt and equity securities; and 
(iv) Congress approved an increase in the ceiling on deposit insurance from P250,000 to 
P500,000 per depositor to more closely align with recent adjustments in deposit guarantees in 
the region; With these preemptive measures in place, indicators show signs of improvement. 
Bank liquidity eased at the end of 2008 and bank lending continued robust growth at about 20% 
in the first quarter of 2009 on a year-on-year basis; the stock market and the peso have 
stabilized  since  November;  and  yields  on  short-  and  medium-term  (3 months  to  5  years) 
domestic  bonds  fell  back  to  precrisis  rates,  although  yields  on  longer-term  bonds  remain 
elevated. 
 
17.  Public Finances. With the sharp contraction in global demand since September 2008, 
and the recognition by the Government and development partners that a larger fiscal expansion 
is necessary, the Government revised its fiscal program for 2009. It now projects a national 
government  budget  deficit  of  3.2%  of  GDP  to  reflect  the  first  quarter  budget  outturn  and 
changes in the budget's macroeconomic assumptions (Table 2). The revised budget deficit

8   
translates to an actual fiscal expansion of up to 2.3% of GDP from 2008,6 low by regional 
standards.7 It covers about 40%–50% of the expected negative output gap this year (i.e., the 
gap between potential and actual economic growth), suggesting that the expansion will have a 
moderate impact on mitigating the economic contraction (Appendix 6). 
 
18.  The Government has announced its revised medium term goal of a balanced budget and 
decided it should be extended to 2013 instead of 2010 as originally planned, being aware of the 
need to provide investors with a sign of its commitment to maintaining a credible fiscal program 
with clear priorities. It targets a national government budget deficit of 2.5% in 2010 (primarily 
achieved by cutting discretionary spending back to its medium-term spending targets), 1.5% in 
2011, and 0.5% in 2012; and a balanced budget by 2013. Recognizing its commitment to fiscal 
prudence and overall sound macroeconomic management, Moody's upgraded the country’s 
sovereign credit rating from Ba3 to Ba1 with a stable outlook. The upgrade was prompted by the 
relatively high degree of resiliency in the banking system and the external balance-of-payments 
situation. The other two major rating agencies maintained the 2008 Philippines’ sovereign credit 
ratings of BB– stable (Standard & Poor’s) and BB stable (Fitch).  
 
19.  The medium-term fiscal targets are realistic and achievable, but will require increased 
effort to increase revenues by about 1 percentage point of GDP from 2010 to 2012. While the 
decline in tax collection is substantially attributable to the economic contraction in the first 
quarter of 2009, weak tax administration and inefficiencies in tax policy have also resulted in 
BIR being unable to increase value-added tax collections through improvements in tax efficiency 
and enforcement. Increasing tax revenue collection is a long-term challenge for the Government. 
Its  approach  is  threefold:  (i)  implement  tax  administration  reforms;  (ii)  enhance  and 
institutionalize anticorruption initiatives in BIR and BOC; and (iii) improve tax policies. Some 
progress in reforms to tax administration has been made under subprogram 3 of the DPSP, 
albeit gradual and incremental. BIR has prioritized the institutionalization of its anticorruption 
revenue  program  (Run  After  Tax  Evaders  or  RATE).  Lessons  from  the  second  DPSP 
subprogram8 indicate  that  these  initiatives  must  be  institutionalized  within  the  agencies  to 
ensure  they  are  sustainable,  permanent,  and  effective  deterrents  to  tax  evasion.  The 
Government  submitted  amendments  to  tax  legislation  (excise  tax  and  consolidation  of 
investment tax incentives) to enhance tax policy efficiency and broaden the tax base; and 
proposed  simplifying  net  income  taxation  for  individuals  in  business.  Once  approved  by 
Congress, these legislative measures are estimated to increase tax collection by P35 billion in 
the first full year of operation.

IV.  THE GOVERNMENT'S COUNTERCYCLICAL EXPENDITURE PROGRAM 
20.  The  Government  announced  its  countercyclical  expenditure  program  in  2009  and 
integrated it into the 2009 budget. The national government budget does not have automatic 
stabilizers embedded on the expenditure side of the budget. Therefore it had to announce the 
countercyclical expenditure program focusing on advancing infrastructure projects already in the 
investment  pipeline,  scaling  up  social  assistance  and  public  employment  programs,  and 
introducing policy measures to expedite budget disbursements. Overall, noninterest expenditure 
is programmed to rise by 20% in 2009 over 2008, providing a much-needed boost to the 
economy. The 2009 national budget substantially increases spending on social sectors to help 
mitigate adverse impacts of the economic contraction on the poor. In real terms (i.e., inflation-
adjusted), the Department of Social Welfare and Development's budget for 2009 has doubled 
compared with the 2008 budget (primarily for funding the conditional cash transfer program); 
education expenditure has increased by 10% and health spending by 19%. Overall, spending 
on social sectors increased from 27% of the budget in 2005 to 31% in 2009. The PHI-CS in 
particular will support the Government's ongoing and scaled up social assistance programs and 
infrastructure programs in the social sector and agriculture included in the 2009 budget and 
proposed 2010 budget (Table 3 and Development Policy letter in Appendix 1).

22.  Social  Programs.  The  social  assistance  programs  are  implemented  within  the 
framework of the Government's national social welfare program. In February 2007, the National 
Economic and Development Authority passed a national definition of social protection and the 
types of programs covered by it. As the next step, the Government established an institutional

23.  The Government has scaled up its social assistance and poverty reduction programs to 
protect the most vulnerable from the effects of the economic contraction. These programs 
include the hunger mitigation program, self-employment assistance kaunlaran (SEA-K) program, 
food for school program, family-based conditional cash transfer (CCT) program, and the new 
crisis-related comprehensive livelihood and emergency employment program (CLEEP), and the 
community-based  development  program  (Kalahi).  These  are  a  combination  of  short-term 
programs  to  mitigate  the  worst  effects  of  the  crisis  on  the  most  vulnerable  people  in  the

supplemented ongoing PFM reforms with additional measures to expedite disbursements to

transparent programs. Many of the key procurement ministries, such as the Department of 
Agriculture,  Department  of  Education,  Department  of  Public  Works  and  Highways,  and 
Department of Transportation and Communication, have relatively low absorptive capacity and 
utilization  rates  that  could  undermine  Government  efforts  to  stimulate  the  economy.

cash  release  basis  that  improves  budget  certainty  and  predictability  for  line  ministries;

receipt of these allotments (clarification provided by the Government Procurement Policy Board, 
which oversees implementation of the procurement reform law). Prior to this circular, agencies 
would not begin the procurement process until they received budget allotments—causing delays 
in  the  procurement  process.  These  new  actions  have  improved  the  efficiency  of  budget 
disbursements.

V.  ECONOMIC AND POVERTY IMPACT OF THE COUNTERCYCLICAL EXPENDITURE 
PROGRAM 
28.  Economic Stimulus Effects. The national government budget deficit is projected at 
3.2% of GDP or an expansion of 2.4% over 2008 (deficit of 0.9% in 2008). An ADB assessment 
indicates that the stimulus effect of the expansion will be less than 2.4% of GDP as it depends 
on the type of spending activities in the stimulus package, and their multiplier effects and timing 
(Appendix 6). For example, tax breaks of P36 billion are likely to expand GDP by less than this 
amount  as  some  proportion  will  be  saved,  while  the  social  assistance  and  labor-intensive 
infrastructure spending program of P160 billion are likely to stimulate the economy by up to 
P192 billion (multiplier of 1.2). These programs are likely to have an immediate impact because 
of their short disbursement periods. Some of the larger infrastructure projects, however, will take 
up to 12 months to have an impact due to the longer procurement and disbursements periods. 
 
29.  Poverty Impacts. An economic slowdown or contraction of about −0.5% to 1.8% in 
2009 will reduce per capita incomes ranging from –0.2% to –2.5%. This is expected to increase 
poverty in the short term because of the weak labor market and reduced household earnings. 
Over the medium term, a slow economic recovery will create persistently high unemployment 
and suppressed earnings in the informal sector as new labor market entrants outnumber the 
new jobs created. Structural poverty may persist as poor families' access to social services is 
reduced. The Government's fiscal stimulus will partially offset the unemployment and poverty 
impacts of the crisis; however, an economic recovery of about 5%–6% in 2011 is necessary to 
ensure a sustained reduction in poverty. The CCT and employment programs (Table 3) will 
have an immediate impact on the welfare of families, and are reaching a significant number of 
people likely to be affected by the crisis (Appendix 6). However, some of these programs (such 
as the subsidized rice program) are not well targeted; this will undermine their effectiveness.

VII.  IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 
 
A.  Countercyclical Support Management 
 
33.  DOF, as the Executing Agency, will report to ADB, administer and disburse the loan 
proceeds, and maintain accounts. The coordinating committee initiated under the DPSP, and 
chaired by the DOF undersecretary, will be responsible for coordinating implementation of the 
Government's  countercyclical  expenditure  program  together  with  DBM  and  the  National 
Economic  and  Development  Authority.  The  committee  will  meet  semi-annually  to  monitor 
progress and oversee the Government's countercyclical expenditure program implementation. 
ADB may be invited to participate in the meetings as an observer.  
 
B.  Procurement and Disbursement  
 
34.  The loan will be released in a single tranche upon loan effectiveness. The loan proceeds 
will be used to finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items 
produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  no  more  than  180  days  before  the 
effectiveness date of the loan. Items specified in the list of ineligible items (Appendix 8) and 
imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources are excluded. In accordance with the 
provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for 
Program Loans (1998), the loan proceeds will be disbursed to the Republic of the Philippines as 
the Borrower. No supporting import documentation will be required if during each year that loan 
proceeds are expected to be disbursed the value of Philippines total imports minus imports from 
nonmember countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under other official development 
assistance is equal to or greater than the amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during 
such year. The Government will certify its compliance with this formula with each withdrawal 
request.  Otherwise,  import  documentation  under  existing  procedures  will  be  required. 
Disbursements will be made under the simplified procedures for program loans. In accordance 
with the simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for program loans, all 
goods and services produced and originating in ADB member countries will be procured, with 
due consideration to economy and efficiency, in accordance with the Government’s standard 
public procedures and normal private sector commercial practices acceptable to ADB. Goods 
commonly traded on the international commodity market will be procured in accordance with 
procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB.  
 
C.  Anticorruption and Fiduciary Issues 
 
35.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the PHI-CS. To support these 
efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the loan regulations 
and the bidding documents for the PHI-CS. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB in 
connection with the PHI-CS shall include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and 
examine the records and accounts of the Executing Agency and all contractors, suppliers, 
consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the PHI-CS. 
 
36.  The country’s financial management systems were assessed based on diagnostic work 
done  in  the  last  12  months  including  the  public  expenditure  and  financial  accountability 
assessment led by the World Bank, with ADB participation during the first stage. Based on this 
assessment, the fiduciary arrangements proposed for the PHI-CS loan remain acceptable. The

SUMMARY OF DEBT SUSTAINABILITY ASSESSMENT 
 
1.  The International Monetary Fund (IMF) undertook an Article IV Consultation with the 
Philippines  in  November  2008.1 As  part  of  its  consultations,  the  IMF  undertook  a  debt 
sustainability assessment (DSA) based on different economic growth, interest rate, primary 
budget balance, and exchange rate shocks. The IMF updated its DSA for the purposes of the 
PHI-CS. This appendix summarizes the pertinent findings of the DSA as well as the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) assessment of the countercyclical expenditure program support loan 
using the IMF DSA as input.  
 
2.  The Philippines' public sector debt is broadly sustainable, but short-term risks have 
increased due to global financial instability. Public debt as a share of GDP has declined to ratios 
last seen in the early 1990s, but remains high by regional standards. At the end of 2008, 
national government public debt amounted to 56% of GDP, down from its peak of 83% in 2003 
(Figure A3). Nonfinancial public sector (NFPS) debt declined to 59.9% from 101.0% during the 
same period (Figure A3). A prudent borrowing strategy, including lengthening the average 
maturity of debt to 7.1 years and moving to domestic financing;2 fiscal discipline (operating 
primary budget surpluses); and sustained economic growth contributed to the rapid decline. 
Debt servicing costs as a share of national government budget revenues also declined from 
36.7% in 2005 to 22.6% in 2007, thereby freeing up substantial resources for priority spending 
since 2007. However, at 8% of GDP, the Philippines’ public debt servicing costs (amortization 
and interest payments) are high by regional standards. The debt amortization profile is lumpy 
with $8.4 billion in external public debt maturing in 2009 and 2010, increasing pressure on the 
Government’s gross financing needs (Figure A3).  
 
3.  The updated IMF DSA indicates that public sector debt is broadly sustainable. In the 
baseline scenario, no new fiscal measures are introduced over the medium term apart from 
planned reduction of the corporate income tax rate in 2009. In this scenario, the nonfinancial 
sector public debt initially rises to about 65% in 2009/2010 and then declines back to 60% of 
GDP in 2014. While debt dynamics are favorable overall, they remain vulnerable to shocks, 
especially exchange rate fluctuations, as 40% of public debt is external. For example, the IMF 
simulated a one-time permanent real depreciation of 30%, which led to a 20 percentage point 
increase in the external debt ratio from 2009, which would remain close to 80% in the medium 
term. The assessment also notes rising resilience to interest rate and growth shocks. Given the 
lengthening of maturities and increasing utilization of domestic financing, external debt is less 
affected by world interest rates and domestic growth shocks. It is only moderately affected by 
noninterest shocks to the current account. The DSA also simulates the impact of lower primary 
budget surpluses on debt over the medium term. It assumes a reduction in the average surplus 
from 2.7% of GDP to 1.3%. Under this scenario, the NFPS debt would be 64% in 2014. The 
various scenarios are summarized in Table A3, with the baseline NFPS debt at 60% of GDP by 
2014. 
 
4.  Implications of the Countercyclical Support Facility Loan. The loan of $500 million 
has  a  term  of  5  years  with  a  3-year  grace  period.  Two  principal  repayments,  each  of  
$250 million, will be made in the fourth and fifth year, i.e., 2013 and 2014. The loan is equivalent 
to 0.3% of GDP, suggesting that in general the underlying sustainability scenarios are not 
significantly impacted by the loan.

DESCRIPTION OF THE DEVELOPMENT POLICY SUPPORT PROGRAM  
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) country strategy and program 2005–2007 for the 
Philippines identifies three key priorities for ADB assistance to ensure a strategically focused 
program.1 Program  selectivity  was  guided  by  country-specific  constraints—macroeconomic 
instability (fiscal consolidation and public financial management [PFM]), investment climate, and 
social  sectors.  ADB  operations  were  designed  to  address  these  constraints  under  three 
corresponding  pillars  in  a  comprehensive  and  integrated  approach  to  development.  The 
Development Policy Support Program (DPSP), approved by the ADB Board of Directors on 8 
February  2007,  operationalizes  the  strategy  by  providing  an  umbrella  operation  that 
complements and reinforces ADB’s sector program loans and projects. The DPSP, structured 
as a program cluster, aims to help the Government achieve its medium- to long-term goals of 
sustained high economic growth of 6%–7% per annum, lower unemployment, and poverty 
reduction. 
 
2.  To achieve these objectives, the DPSP undertakes the following strategic reforms: 
 
(i)  Improve  fiscal  sustainability,  maintain  macroeconomic  stability,  and  improve 
creditworthiness by enhancing the quality of fiscal management by (a) increasing 
tax  revenues  annually  through  tax  policy  reforms;  (b)  strengthening  tax 
administration  and  enforcement,  and  reducing  revenue  leakages  through 
improved governance; (c) reducing inefficient spending to permit increased social 
and  poverty-related  spending;  and  (d)  strengthening  the  debt  management 
strategy  to  manage  government  contingent  liabilities  and  risks  prudently. 
Subprogram 3 of the DPSP aims to maintain macroeconomic stability under the 
current  adverse  global  financial  environment  by  reassuring  depositors' 
confidence in the domestic banking system. 
(ii)  Enhance governance in PFM by (a) improving PFM from budget preparation 
through  to  budget  execution,  accounting,  recording,  and  reporting; 
(b) strengthening  performance  management  and  improving  public  service 
delivery;  (c)  reforming  procurement;  and  (d)  implementing  anticorruption  and 
enforcement  strategies  for  revenue-collecting  agencies  and  key  procurement 
agencies. Subprogram 3 sustains critical public expenditures while maintaining 
budget discipline to mitigate the poverty impacts of the deceleration of growth. 
(iii)  Improve the investment climate and promote rural development by (a) clarifying 
and strengthening the legal and regulatory framework for investments and trade, 
(b)  facilitating  infrastructure  development  through  greater  public–private 
participation and greater coordination of public infrastructure investments, and 
(c) improving rural–urban connectivity. 
(iv)  Enhance human capital and social inclusion by improving the policy framework 
for social protection, sustaining real spending on health and education, improving 
targeting  of  programs,  piloting  the  conditional  cash  transfer  program  tied  to 
performance outcomes in child education and health, refining public employment 
programs, and establishing a national poverty monitoring and response system

2.  Another way of looking at economic performance is the output gap, which measures the

B.   Impact of the Government's Countercyclical Public Spending Program   
 
4.  Economic  Stimulus  Effects. In times of a negative output gap, governments may 
stimulate the economy through a combination of policy instruments such as (i) expansionary 
monetary policy and therefore lowering interest rates to stimulate investment and consumption, 
and (ii) fiscal expansion through tax cuts and increasing discretionary public spending. An 
appropriate fiscal expansion will depend on its size relative to the output gap and the multiplier 
(or second-round effects) of the different components of the fiscal stimulus. Empirical evidence 
for  other  countries  indicates  that  infrastructure  spending  has  the  largest  multiplier  effects, 
followed by cash transfers to poor families; tax breaks have the lowest multiplier effects as 
some proportion will be saved. 
 
5.  The Government is using both instruments to stimulate the economy. In aggregate, the 
national government budget deficit is projected at 3.2% of GDP or an expansion of 2.4% over 
2008 (budget deficit of 0.9% in 2008). This expansion is equivalent to about 40%–50% of the 
negative output gap. The stimulus effect of the expansion will be less than 2.4% of GDP and 
depends on the stimulus components and their multiplier effects and timing:

amount as some proportion will be saved (multiplier less than 1.0).

programs  are  likely  to  have  an  immediate  impact  due  their  short 
disbursement periods. Some of the larger projects, however, will take up to 
12 months to have an impact due to longer procurement and disbursement 
periods. 
(iii)  The  infrastructure  programs  of  government-owned  and  -controlled 
corporations amounting to P100 billion could also stimulate the economy by 
up to P120 billion. Some of the projects of the larger corporations will also

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.   Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Philippines. The Countercyclical Support (PHI-CS) loan 
provides financing support to the Government's countercyclical public expenditure program aimed at stimulating the economy, 
protecting spending in the social sectors, and scaling up flagship social assistance programs to protect vulnerable groups in 
the community from adverse impacts of the global financial crisis. The national government budget does not have automatic 
stabilizers embedded on the expenditure side of the budget. Therefore it had to introduce a countercyclical expenditure 
program focusing on advancing infrastructure projects already in the investment pipeline, scaling up social assistance and 
public employment programs, and introducing policy measures to expedite budget disbursements. Overall, noninterest 
expenditure is programmed to rise by 20% in 2009 over 2008 providing a much-needed boost to the economy. The 2009 
national budget substantially increases spending on the social sectors. The Department of Social Welfare and Development's 
budget has doubled in real terms (i.e., inflation-adjusted) compared with its 2008 budget (primarily for funding the conditional 
cash transfer program); education expenditure has increased by 10% in real terms; and health spending by 19% in real terms. 
Overall, spending on the social sectors has increased from 27% of the budget in 2005 to 31% in 2009.  
 
The PHI-CS loan supplements Asian Development Bank (ADB) program loans to the Philippines and in particular the 
Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP)  cluster.  The  DPSP  policy  areas  largely  correspond  with  those  of  the 
Government as spelled out in the Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan 2004–2010, which focuses on five core areas: 
(i) economic growth and job creation, (ii) energy dependency and power reforms, (iii) social justice and basic needs, (iv) 
education and youth opportunities, and (v) anticorruption measures and governance. The plan‘s mission is to “fight poverty by 
building prosperity for the greatest number of Filipino people.”  
 
The Government has made substantial progress in addressing fiscal consolidation and in 2008 shifted focus to ensuring 
sustainable fiscal policy by enhancing tax revenues over the longer term. This is necessary to increase social expenditures. 
However, the global financial crisis and second-round effect of devastated external demand has hurt the Philippine economy. 
Fiscal pressures come from two sources: (i) increased public demand for additional social spending to mitigate poverty 
impacts, and (ii) a decline in budget revenues in the first quarter of 2009. The challenge faced by the Government is to protect 
recent gains in social expenditures, plus provide additional assistance through its social programs such as the conditional 
cash transfer program; provide a fiscal stimulus through increased infrastructure spending; and ensure medium-term debt 
sustainability. Consequently, the national government budget deficit will rise to 3.2% of gross domestic product this year and 
2% in 2010. This protects critical public spending and ensures fiscal discipline.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues. The apparent recessionary conditions in the Philippine economy threaten to reverse recent gains in reducing 
unemployment, which steadily declined during the last 2 years. Most recently, unemployment increased from 7.3% to 7.6%. 
Economic growth in 2009 is estimated at -0.5%–1.8%, this translates to a decline in per capita income of –2.5% to –0.2%. 
This would result in an increase in the incidence of poverty. A decrease in remittances would add to poverty. Mitigating the 
poverty impacts, the Government piloted the CCT program with 337,345 families in 2008 and 2009, and is expected broaden 
the program to 699,000 families in 2009. The experience of Indonesia with its unconditional cash transfer has been positive in 
terms of keeping vulnerable families out of poverty during hard times such as now. 
 
2. Design Features. The PHI-CS loan will provide budget support for the Government's countercyclical public expenditure 
program in infrastructure and the social sectors. It aims to ensure predictability in budget financing for 2009 as a larger 
national government budget deficit is required than initially projected.  
 
C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Lending  
The PHI-CS loan supports the Government's countercyclical public expenditure program for 2009. The program includes the 
hunger mitigation program, self-employment assistance kaunlaran (SEA-K) program, food for school program, family-based 
CCT  program,  and  comprehensive  livelihood  and  emergency  employment  program  (CLEEP).  These  programs  are  a 
combination of short-term programs to mitigate the worst effects of the crisis on the most vulnerable people in the community 
and longer-term programs aimed at addressing causes of poverty such as limited access to education and health services for 
children.

ADB assessments suggest that the possible decline in per capita income this year and increase in unemployment and poverty
